articles.headline: Clinton Is Said to Accept Secretary of State Position
articles.snippet: Two confidants said Hillary Rodham Clinton would give up her Senate seat and accept the nomination for secretary of state after talks with the president-elect.
articles.abstract: Two confidants said Hillary Rodham Clinton would give up her Senate seat and accept the nomination for secretary of state after talks with the president-elect.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Hillary Rodham Clinton has decided to give up her Senate seat to become secretary of state in the Obama administration, making her the public face to the world for the man who dashed her own hopes for the presidency, confidants of Mrs. Clinton said Friday.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Helene Cooper

articles.headline: Leaner Holiday Gift Giving, Bountiful in Spirit
articles.snippet: At a time when so many people have so much less than they did just a few months ago, there ought to be a way to lessen the gift-giving pressure.
articles.abstract: At a time when so many people have so much less than they did just a few months ago, there ought to be a way to lessen the gift-giving pressure.
articles.lead_paragraph: Of all years, this may be the one to stop the holiday gift madness — out of necessity for some of us or simply out of reason.

articles.headline: That Money Isn’t Leaving the Vault
articles.snippet: When the Treasury gave taxpayer billions to the banks, it attached no strings. So is it any surprise that lending is tight?
articles.abstract: When the Treasury gave taxpayer billions to the banks, it attached no strings. So is it any surprise that lending is tight?
articles.lead_paragraph: SO goes the old saw about bankers: they loan you an umbrella when the sun is shining, only to ask for it back when it rains.

articles.headline: Lawyers Wanted: Abroad, That Is
articles.snippet: As the economic downturn continues, a growing number of lawyers are starting to look overseas for work.
articles.abstract: As the economic downturn continues, a growing number of lawyers are starting to look overseas for work.
articles.lead_paragraph: SARAH N. GLENN, a fourth-year associate at the venerable law firm of Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy, is moving to Japan in January.

articles.headline: Now, Brevity Is the Soul of Office Interaction
articles.snippet: Microblogging is gaining ground at work, becoming popular for both internal and external exchanges.
articles.abstract: Microblogging is gaining ground at work, becoming popular for both internal and external exchanges.
articles.lead_paragraph: ONE hundred forty characters  the exact length of this sentence  is turning out to be just right for business communications of all kinds.

articles.headline: Shares Falling, Citigroup Talks to Government
articles.snippet: Options discussed included a public endorsement from the government or a new financial lifeline.
articles.abstract: Options discussed included a public endorsement from the government or a new financial lifeline.
articles.lead_paragraph: With the sharp stock-market decline for Citigroup rapidly becoming a full-blown crisis of confidence, the company’s executives on Friday entered into talks with federal officials about how to stabilize the struggling financial giant.
articles.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Louise Story

articles.headline: G.M.’s Latest Great Green Hope Is a Tall Order
articles.snippet: The Chevrolet Volt is the centerpiece of G.M.’s strategy to convince Congress of the strength of its business plan.
articles.abstract: The Chevrolet Volt is the centerpiece of G.M.’s strategy to convince Congress of the strength of its business plan.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  The Chevrolet Volt, a plug-in hybrid, will not arrive in showrooms until late 2010. But it is already straining under the weight of an entire company.

articles.headline: Road Ahead Is Long for G.M.
articles.snippet: Bankruptcy is a long, difficult, drawn-out process with no guarantee that a judge will go along with G.M.’s desires.
articles.abstract: Bankruptcy is a long, difficult, drawn-out process with no guarantee that a judge will go along with G.M.’s desires.
articles.lead_paragraph: Is it really possible that General Motors has not yet begun drawing up contingency plans for a bankruptcy filing  as the chief executive, Rick Wagoner, told Congress this week?

articles.headline: Fed Official Is Said to Be Choice for Treasury
articles.snippet: The news that Timothy F. Geithner would be named Treasury secretary helped drive stocks sharply higher.
articles.abstract: The news that Timothy F. Geithner would be named Treasury secretary helped drive stocks sharply higher.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President-elect Barack Obama will name Timothy F. Geithner, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, to be his Treasury secretary, moving to fill a key post at a moment when the quavering financial markets are looking for reassurance about the direction of economic policy, people briefed about the decision said Friday.

articles.headline: Obama Tilts to Center, Inviting a Clash of Ideas
articles.snippet: President-elect Barack Obama’s reported selections for two major cabinet jobs suggest a preference for pragmatists, not ideologues.
articles.abstract: President-elect Barack Obama’s reported selections for two major cabinet jobs suggest a preference for pragmatists, not ideologues.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President-elect Barack Obama won the Democratic nomination with the enthusiastic support of the left wing of his party, fueled by his vehement opposition to the decision to invade Iraq and by one of the most liberal voting records in the Senate.

articles.headline: Woes at Citigroup Began With Failed Bid for Wachovia
articles.snippet: In a stunning turnabout, the banking giant has sunk to its knees and is running short on time and options.
articles.abstract: In a stunning turnabout, the banking giant has sunk to its knees and is running short on time and options.
articles.lead_paragraph: Less than two months ago, Citigroup emerged from the wreckage of the financial crisis as one of the last titans left standing on Wall Street.
articles.byline: By Ben White and Vikas Bajaj

articles.headline: A Friendship’s Paying Off for British Banking Giant
articles.snippet: Barclays executive Roger Jenkins forged relationships with several Middle Eastern investors who put $8.6 billion into Barclays.
articles.abstract: Barclays executive Roger Jenkins forged relationships with several Middle Eastern investors who put $8.6 billion into Barclays.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON  The top executives of Barclays have given up their bonuses, but do not expect Roger Jenkins to forgo his.

articles.headline: Hints of Relief From the Siege
articles.snippet: Reports that Timothy F. Geithner would lead the Treasury Department were seen as a sign of continuity to a new administration.
articles.abstract: Reports that Timothy F. Geithner would lead the Treasury Department were seen as a sign of continuity to a new administration.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Caught flat-footed by the latest panic in the financial markets and a potentially life-threatening crisis at Citigroup, the Treasury Department is planning another round of emergency measures intended to restore normalcy.
articles.byline: By Edmund L. Andrews and Mark Landler

articles.headline: Obama Vows Swift Action on Vast Economic Stimulus Plan
articles.snippet: Barack Obama offered the outlines of a plan to create or save 2.5 million jobs by investing in public works and alternative energy.
articles.abstract: Barack Obama offered the outlines of a plan to create or save 2.5 million jobs by investing in public works and alternative energy.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President-elect Barack Obama signaled on Saturday that he would pursue a far more ambitious plan of spending and tax cuts than anything he outlined on the campaign trail, setting the tone for a recovery effort that could absorb and define much of his term.
articles.byline: By Jackie Calmes and Jeff Zeleny

articles.headline: Clinton-Obama Détente: From Top Rival to Top Aide
articles.snippet: Few are predicting that a new relationship born of mutual respect and self-interest will grow into a tight bond, but it might.
articles.abstract: Few are predicting that a new relationship born of mutual respect and self-interest will grow into a tight bond, but it might.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The thaw in the resentful relationship between the most powerful woman in the Democratic Party and her younger male rival began at the party’s convention this summer, when Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton gave such a passionate speech supporting Senator Barack Obama that his top aides leapt out of their chairs backstage to give her a standing ovation as she swept past.

articles.headline: Citigroup Saw No Red Flags Even as It Made Bolder Bets
articles.snippet: Much of the damage inflicted on Citigroup was caused by errant, high-octane trading and lax oversight, critics say.
articles.abstract: Much of the damage inflicted on Citigroup was caused by errant, high-octane trading and lax oversight, critics say.
articles.lead_paragraph: “Our job is to set a tone at the top to incent people to do the right thing and to set up safety nets to catch people who make mistakes or do the wrong thing and correct those as quickly as possible. And it is working. It is working.”
articles.byline: By Eric Dash and Julie Creswell

articles.headline: After Disney, Eisner Finds a Home Online
articles.snippet: Michael Eisner has settled into a comfortable post-Disney existence, staking a claim on Web entertainment.
articles.abstract: Michael Eisner has settled into a comfortable post-Disney existence, staking a claim on Web entertainment.
articles.lead_paragraph: ON a Friday morning in September, Michael D. Eisner was in a television studio on the East Side of Manhattan, asking Robert L. Nardelli, the chairman of Chrysler, whether he nursed a grudge against Jack Welch for passing him over for the top job at General Electric eight years ago.

articles.headline: Ringed by Foes, Pakistanis Fear the U.S., Too
articles.snippet: There is an increasing belief among some Pakistanis that what the U.S. really wants is the breakup of Pakistan.
articles.abstract: There is an increasing belief among some Pakistanis that what the U.S. really wants is the breakup of Pakistan.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — A redrawn map of South Asia has been making the rounds among Pakistani elites. It shows their country truncated, reduced to an elongated sliver of land with the big bulk of India to the east, and an enlarged Afghanistan to the west.

articles.headline: Citigroup to Halt Dividend and Curb Pay
articles.snippet: Citigroup will effectively halt dividend payments and agree to certain restrictions on executive compensation.
articles.abstract: Citigroup will effectively halt dividend payments and agree to certain restrictions on executive compensation.
articles.lead_paragraph: As part of a rescue agreement with federal regulators, Citigroup will effectively halt dividend payments for the next three years and will agree to restrictions on and review of certain executive compensation, it was announced on Monday. The bank will also put in place the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation’s loan modification plan, which is similar to one it recently announced.

articles.headline: Google Seduces With Utility
articles.snippet: Some call it Big Brother, but who can resist? It’s just so darn useful.
articles.abstract: Some call it Big Brother, but who can resist? It’s just so darn useful.
articles.lead_paragraph: Not long ago, someone invited me out to the Googleplex, the nickname for Google’s headquarters in Mountain View, Calif.

articles.headline: Big Three’s Troubles May Touch Financial Sector
articles.snippet: Detroit’s largest automakers owe more than $100 billion, and Wall Street is wondering how much will be paid back.
articles.abstract: Detroit’s largest automakers owe more than $100 billion, and Wall Street is wondering how much will be paid back.
articles.lead_paragraph: To the long list of troubles plaguing the financial industry, add three big ones  make that Big Three ones.
articles.byline: By Zachery Kouwe and Louise Story

articles.headline: Ford Scion Looks Beyond Bailout to Green Agenda
articles.snippet: William C. Ford Jr. could play a critical role in how the Obama administration decides to aid the auto industry.
articles.abstract: William C. Ford Jr. could play a critical role in how the Obama administration decides to aid the auto industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: DEARBORN, Mich.  As the Detroit auto companies contend with their worst financial crisis in decades, the most famous American auto executive has stayed largely out of sight.

articles.headline: For Luxury Brands, Less Money to Spend on Ads
articles.snippet: The drop-off in advertising spending by luxury brands means more bad news for magazines and newspapers in the United States.
articles.abstract: The drop-off in advertising spending by luxury brands means more bad news for magazines and newspapers in the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: Gold was raining from above for luxury brands in the good old days of 2007.

articles.headline: As Taboos Ease, Saudi Girl Group Dares to Rock
articles.snippet: Saudi Arabia’s first all-girl rock band has an underground hit as the country’s harsh code of morals slowly thaws.
articles.abstract: Saudi Arabia’s first all-girl rock band has an underground hit as the country’s harsh code of morals slowly thaws.
articles.lead_paragraph: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia  They cannot perform in public. They cannot pose for album cover photographs. Even their jam sessions are secret, for fear of offending the religious authorities in this ultraconservative kingdom.

articles.headline: An Old Hometown Mentor, Still at Obama’s Side
articles.snippet: Valerie Jarrett, who is heading to the White House, helped the Obamas get to where they are today.
articles.abstract: Valerie Jarrett, who is heading to the White House, helped the Obamas get to where they are today.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO  On a dark afternoon last week, the road to Jerusalem and Beijing momentarily veered through the office of a real estate company here.

articles.headline: Rubinomics Recalculated
articles.snippet: Barack Obama’s economic team has many protégés of Robert E. Rubin, but they reject old orthodoxies.
articles.abstract: Barack Obama’s economic team has many protégés of Robert E. Rubin, but they reject old orthodoxies.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  It is testament to former Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin’s star power among many Democrats that as President-elect Barack Obama fills out his economic team, a virtual Rubin constellation is taking shape.

articles.headline: Owed Back Pay, Guest Workers Comb the Past
articles.snippet: Guest farm workers can now collect a payment of wages, decades overdue, from the Mexican government.
articles.abstract: Guest farm workers can now collect a payment of wages, decades overdue, from the Mexican government.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRESNO, Calif.  Here comes Abraham Franco now, 86 years old, skin leathery and bronzed from decades of work in the fields, slowly bending his small but sturdy frame into a metal chair at a faux wood office table at the Mexican Consulate here.

articles.headline: Awaiting Reaction to 3rd Try at Bailout
articles.snippet: The question, as a new week begins, is whether this plan will produce lasting effects not only for Citigroup but also for the broader stock market.
articles.abstract: The question, as a new week begins, is whether this plan will produce lasting effects not only for Citigroup but also for the broader stock market.
articles.lead_paragraph: Will the third time be the charm?

articles.headline: Another Crisis, Another Guarantee
articles.snippet: Will the latest rescue by the U.S. government finally restore confidence in the American financial system?
articles.abstract: Will the latest rescue by the U.S. government finally restore confidence in the American financial system?
articles.lead_paragraph: Guarantees that could not be honored thrust the world financial system into its worst crisis since the Great Depression. Will a guarantee by the United States government finally restore confidence in the American financial system?
